Use your voice to control your Sonos system with any voice-enabled Sonos product—play and control content, turn the volume up or down, and more.
: Voice control isn’t supported in every country yet—this feature will be available as soon as Sonos and a voice service launch together in your region.
The microphone is used for voice control and for microphone-dependent features like Trueplay tuning. Press
to turn the microphone on or off—the microphone LED light will let you know when your voice assistant is listening.
When the microphone light is on
When the microphone light is off

Every room is different. Trueplay tuning measures how sound reflects off walls, furnishings, and other surfaces in a room, then fine tunes your Sonos speaker to make sure it sounds great no matter where you've placed it.
Trueplay works on iOS mobile devices running iOS 8 or later. During tuning, you'll move around the room holding your mobile device.

Portable Sonos products like Sonos Roam and Move can tune themselves automatically. Auto Trueplay uses your speaker’s microphone to detect the environment and make periodic tuning adjustments so you get great sound wherever your speaker is and whatever you're listening to.
, and select your portable speaker to turn on auto Trueplay.

If you move your speaker to a new room, you can change its name in
(not available for Sonos Era 100, Era 300, or portable products)
You can turn off your speaker’s WiFi when it’s connected to your network with an Ethernet cable. This reduces power consumption and can improve connectivity for wired speakers.
For products like Amp and Port, turning off WiFi can reduce the internal temperature when they’re placed in a rack or stacked.
WiFi is turned off for Era 100 and Era 300 when you connect a
Sonos products ship with preset equalization settings. You can change the sound settings (bass, treble, or loudness) to suit your personal preferences.
Trueplay adapts the sound for your surroundings and content. Portable products can tune themselves automatically.
You can set a maximum volume for each room.
Displays the speaker’s connection to WiFi, indicates when the volume is muted, and signals errors.
: If the light is distracting, you can turn it off in
You can disable the touch control on your speaker. You may want to do this to prevent a child or curious pet from accidentally adjusting playback or volume.
To save battery life, you can set your portable speaker to power off automatically instead of going to sleep. It won't appear in the Sonos app until it’s powered back on.

Sonos products for your TV provide full-theater sound and play music too. Create a home theater system by adding a pair of
Use the Sonos app to adjust sound settings or change the way your home theater speaker works with your TV.
If the TV audio is out of sync with the video, you can adjust the audio delay (lip sync) in your room’s settings.
If you notice audio issues when playing to a group, you can adjust this setting.
—if music or other content is playing when you turn on your TV, the audio automatically switches to TV audio (default). If you don’t want this to happen, turn off TV Autoplay in your room’s settings.

—if your home theater speaker is grouped with other products when you turn on the TV, it automatically drops from the group (default). If you don’t want this to happen, turn off Ungroup on Autoplay in your room’s settings.
Makes TV dialog easier to hear.
Enhances quiet sounds and reduces the intensity of loud sounds. Turn on to reduce the volume while still experiencing proper balance and range.
During setup, you’ll program a remote control. You can program a different remote control any time.
It’s easy to turn two Sonos speakers (same model), or a Sonos Amp and your favorite non-Sonos speakers, into separate right and left channels for your home theater.
: If you group the rooms or create a stereo pair instead, you won't have surround sound.

Adjust surround volume for TV audio.
(louder, full range). Doesn't apply to Dolby Atmos Music playback.

. Tape the cardboard template to the wall above or below your TV. Use a level. Keep 1" (25mm) space (minimum) for access to Beam’s touch controls. (Don’t install Beam vertically.)
. Mark the center of the mounting holes and remove the template.
Use a 5/16" drill bit to drill pilot holes.
Insert and secure the wall anchors (don’t use the anchors if drilling into wood).
Place the bracket on the wall and loosely tighten the wall screws to secure the bracket. Check with a level and then tighten the screws.
Connect the power and HDMI cables to Beam.
Insert and tighten Beam to the bracket using the mounting screws.
Four full-range woofers ensure you’ll hear the faithful playback of mid-range vocal frequencies plus deep, rich bass.
One tweeter creates crisp high frequencies and clear dialogue.
Use the Sonos app to adjust bass, treble, and loudness.
Connects to WiFi network with any 802.11 b/g/n, 2.4GHz broadcast-capable router.
One 10/100Mbps Ethernet port. You can wire directly to your router if your WiFi is unstable.

TV with HDMI ARC / eARC port or optical digital audio output, broadband internet, and the Sonos app.
Works with AirPlay 2 on Apple devices iOS 11.4 and higher.
Maps specific sounds in 3D space for a 360° effect.
Dynamically tunes the speaker to the unique acoustics of the room or area (iOS device required).
Turn on this home theater setting in the Sonos app to make TV dialogue even clearer.

When the microphone light is on, voice control is on and your voice service is ready to respond.
When the light is off, voice control is off.
Place horizontally on a stable and level surface at least 2" (50 mm) from the TV.
Don’t place vertically or on its side.
Don’t block the TV’s IR sensor.
If put on a shelf, place at the front and keep 2" (minimum) clearance on both sides for best sound quality.
Keep 1" (25 mm) space (minimum) above Beam so you can reach the touch controls.
For best sound quality, keep both ends of Beam at least 1" (30 mm) from a wall or other obstruction.
Disconnect existing home theater or surround sound equipment from your TV.
Connect any external devices, like a cable box or DVD player, directly to your TV.
If your TV has an HDMI ARC (or eARC) port
, connect the HDMI cable to it.

(HDMI ARC is a special port that looks like a standard HDMI port—it may be on the back or side of your TV. The ports look similar, but the ARC port will be labeled ARC, eARC, or ARC/eARC. If you connect Sonos Beam to a standard HDMI port instead, you won’t hear any sound.)
If your TV doesn’t have an HDMI ARC or eARC port
, you'll need to use the optical adapter:
Remove the protective cap from the optical adapter, then attach the optical adapter to the HDMI cable.
Connect the optical adapter to your TV’s optical digital OUT port.
(The TV's optical adapter’s port is “D-shaped”—make sure the connector aligns correctly into the port. Inserting the adapter incorrectly may damage the cable.)
: control your whole Sonos system with hands-free ease and unmatched privacy. Sonos Voice Control comes ready to use—it only takes a few seconds to add when you set up your speakers.
: you’ll need the Sonos app and the Alexa app with the Sonos skill enabled. You’ll make some changes in both apps during setup.
: you’ll need the Sonos app and the Google Assistant app. You’ll make some changes in both apps during setup.

: you’ll need the Apple Home app. Add your AirPlay2-compatible Sonos speakers to the Apple Home app and then use an iPhone, iPad, or Apple TV to ask Siri to play music (currently limited to Apple Music).
If you set up a voice service, voice control is on and ready to respond.
If you set up a voice service, voice control is off.
Microphone-dependent features like Trueplay are unavailable.

Five far-field microphone array uses advanced beam forming and multi-channel echo cancellation so your voice assistant can be readily activated.
